answers: Pulitzer Prize for Fiction (The other authors are Booth Tarkington, William Faulkner, and John Updike.)
parts: Name this novel set in Tallahassee, in which Elwood dies in an escape from the title reformatory school, while Turner returns 50 years later to give testimony about his friend's death.
The Nickel Boys is by this contemporary author, who wrote about the slave Cora's escape west in The Underground Railroad.

Both The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad won this annual award for distinguished fiction by an American author, which is given out by Columbia University; only three other authors have won this award twice.

answers: parity symmetry [or parity inversion; I suppose prompt on answers indicating a rotation of 180 degrees]
weak force [or the weak nuclear force or weak interaction]
short and long [or short-lived and long-lived, or K-short and K-long]
parts: Name this type of physical symmetry which flips the sign of all spatial coordinates, reflecting the system through the origin.
This force is the only one of the fundamental forces that can violate parity symmetry. This force mediates beta-decay.
The oscillations of kaons between these two eigenstates breaks charge-parity symmetry; those oscillations were used in the Cronin-Fitch experiment to confirm that the weak force violates CP.

answers: Phoenicia [or Phoenicians, or Punic people, or Ponnim]
Indus Valley civilization [or Indus River civilization, or Harappan civilization]
parts: Artifacts from Cishan and Beixin ("bay-shin") support the theory that people in Northern China were the earliest to domesticate which common species of poultry, which evolved from red junglefowl?
Research by Lee Perry-Gal et al attributes the introduction of chickens to Europe to this civilization, whose major cities included Byblos, Sidon, and Utica.
Scholars have suggested that cuneiform inscriptions of the "royal bird of Meluhha" likely refer to chickens raised by this civilization, whose major exports included jewelry made of carnelian.
Name this artist, who organized several bed-ins with her husband John Lennon to protest the Vietnam War.
Self-destructive art was popular amongst this international group of avant-garde artists, of which Ono was a member. George Maciunas was influential in founding this group.

Fluxus members take apart one of these objects in Philip Corner's 1962 piece titled for that object's "activities". Joseph Beuys was inspired by the thalidomide tragedy to cover one of these non-cello objects in felt with a red cross on it.

answers: rakes [or rakehells; accept libertine; prompt on debauchee]
Restoration of the Stuarts [accept Restoration drama]
parts: Name this sort of stock character, exemplified by Horner in The Country Wife, who is typically a profligate degenerate. The author John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester, was himself a prominent example.
Rakes are common in plays from this era of English literature, which is named for the period after Charles II returned to the throne.
This author adapted Tirso de Molina's works about Don Juan for an English audience in his play The Libertine. This author of The Virtuoso became Poet Laureate just after the Glorious Revolution.

answers: ensemble classifiers [or ensemble methods or ensemble forecasting]
parts: Name this class of machine learning methods which average the outputs from multiple classifiers to build a final model. They share their name with a similar method used in weather forecasting.
Ensemble classifiers reduce both bias and this other quantity, avoiding a common tradeoff. Standard deviation is the square root of this quantity.

Many ensemble classifiers use this lazy learning method, which takes a user input of k, then classifies each data point based on the classification of a majority of the k closest training data points in feature space.

answers: chads [accept hanging, swinging, tri-, pregnant, or dimpled chads; prompt on pieces of paper or hole punches]
parts: Name these devices. ES&S, Dominion, and Hart InterCivic are three companies that have a virtual monopoly on selling these devices in the United States.
In this year, Ohio's secretary-of-state controversially offered a $100 million contract to Diebold Election Systems, whose president also voted Republican. George W. Bush was re-elected in this year.
The push for voting machines came after 2000, during which some of these objects were left partially attached to ballot cards in Florida, so votes were not properly tabulated.
This bird was said to tear her chest to feed her own blood to her young; as such, it symbolized charity, sacrifice, and the Eucharist.
These animals' cubs were said to be stillborn for three days until they came alive, and were identified with Jesus. As the highest animal in the Great Chain of Being, it was called "king of beasts".

Medieval Europeans never saw the young of these migratory animals and naturally concluded that they grew from barnacles. Thus, they were considered fish and eaten on fast days until the Fourth Lateran Council banned it.

answers: mind-body problem [accept answers which refer to the distinction of physical and mental states]
New Mysterianism [or New Mysterians; prompt on mysterianism]
parts: Name this philosophical problem. Gilbert Ryle referred to a solution to it introduced in the 17th century as the "ghost in the machine".
The "ghost in the machine" is a critique of this Frenchman's division of the mind and body, called his namesake "dualism". He wrote "I think, therefore I am" in Discourse on the Method.
In such papers as "Can We Solve the Mind-Body Problem?" philosopher Colin McGinn advanced this position, which holds that the "hard problem" of consciousness cannot be solved by humans.

answers: Seattle (The second museum is Frank Gehry's Museum of Pop Culture.)
parts: Name this architect who collaborated with her husband on projects like the Sainsbury Wing. She discussed sexism in architecture in her essay "Room at the Top?"

Scott Brown collaborated with her husband, Robert Venturi, on an art museum in this city. A spiral-shaped sculpture made of hundreds of guitars is a focal point of a Frank Gehry-designed museum in this city.
Scott Brown compared a "duck" with a "decorated shed" in a book co-authored with Venturi and Steven Izenour titled Learning from [this city], whose Strip includes casinos like Bellagio.

answers: Burgess Shale [do not accept or prompt on "shale"]
parts: Name this geologic period whose namesake "explosion" is the sudden appearance of virtually all modern animal phyla in the fossil record. It is the first period in the Paleozoic Era.
Animals like Wiwaxia and Opabinia were discovered in this sedimentary rock deposit in the Canadian Rockies, which has many well-preserved Cambrian fossils.
The earliest direct evidence of molting is a Burgess Shale fossil of this animal mid-molt. This bizarre-looking arthropod is the Burgess Shale's most common animal.

answers: prayer flags [or lungta/rlung rta; or darchog/dar lcog; prompt on flags, banners, or cloths]
parts: Om mani padme hum ("ohm muh-nih pud-may hoom") is the central example of what texts in Tibetan Buddhism? These short phrases are spoken during meditation.
Mantras surround images of the Wind Horse on these objects made by Tibetans. Strands of them are strung in high places so that mantras are picked up by the wind.
Repetitions of mantras are counted with these objects, which may be made of animal or human bone in Tibet. In India, they're known by the Sanskrit term mala ("mah-lah") or "garland".

answers: Yongle emperor [or Zhu Di; prompt on Zhu]
parts: A popular form of execution involved trampling by these animals. Mahouts ("muh-HAUTZ") were people who trained these tusked mammals.

The cangue ("kang"), a popular form of humiliation, was similar to this European form of punishment. Its victims had their head and hands trapped between two wooden boards and were made to stand, unlike the stockades.

After Fang Xiaoru ("fong sh'yow-roo") refused to compare this emperor with the Duke of Zhou ("joe"), he executed ten of Fang's relatives. This emperor suppressed a sex scandal by murdering 2,800 attendants and women of his harem and had all servants of the preceding Jianwen emperor killed.

answers: Taras Bulba (It is a novel by Nikolai Gogol.)
parts: Name this composer and Czech nationalist who drew on Moravian folk music for such operas as Jenůfa.

Janáček wrote two pieces for this ensemble, including one inspired by Leo Tolstoy's novella The Kreutzer Sonata. Other Czech pieces for this chamber ensemble include Smetana's ("SMEH-tah-nah'z") "From My Life" and Dvořák's "American" one.

This other work of Russian literature inspired a "symphonic rhapsody" by Janáček which includes a passage scored for brass and organ that represents the title character's "Prophecy". This work also inspired an opera by Mykola Lysenko.

answers: Kazi Nazrul Islam [prompt on Rebel Poet]
parts: This musician's lyrics for folk songs such as "Tambourine Man" have been included in many literary and poetry anthologies, contributing to his controversial award of the Nobel Prize in 2016.

This medieval French songwriter and poet adapted Parisian thieves's songs in many of his poems. His collection Le Testament ("tes-tah-MON") contains a poem which asks "Where are the snows of yesteryear?"
This Bengali author wrote many songs and poems which have been adapted into a music genre called his namesake Geeti. He wrote "I raise my head beyond this world" in one such poem, "The Rebel".

answers: (golden) spurs [accept Battle of the Golden Spurs]
scutage (It comes from the Latin word scutum.)
parts: After pledging fealty to your lord, you receive the right to one of these pieces of heritable property.
To display your rank, you might wear highly decorative examples of these objects. Following the Battle of Courtrai, 500 pairs of these objects were taken from the troops of Philip IV of France.
If you really, really don't want to go to war anymore, you can instead pay this tax - whose name comes from the Latin for "shield" - thereby buying out your service from the king.

answers: fiscal multiplier [do not accept or prompt on "money multiplier"]
parts: Name these periods which are technically defined by the European Central Bank as two periods of consecutive negative GDP growth.
Modern fiscal policy is typically designed to provide one of these automatic mechanisms to combat recessions, as tax payments decrease and welfare payments increase as GDP declines.

Many economists agree that, during recessions, this quantity increases for each government dollar spent, as the marginal propensity to consume rises during recessions. Tax cuts for wealthy households are estimated to have values of this quantity below 1.

answers: photochemical reactions [accept light-catalyzed reactions or answers indicating the reaction is caused by light; accept photodegradation or pretty much any answer with the prefix photo-]
carbon monoxide [accept CO] (Type I Norrish reactions cleave a carbonyl and join together the two attached R groups, releasing free CO.)
parts: Name this class of reactions. The Woodward-Hoffmann rules predict the stereochemical outcome of thermal reactions and reactions of this type.
Photochemical smog, produced by sunlight reacting with atmospheric pollutants, is rich in this compound, whose normal presence in the stratosphere absorbs solar radiation.
In type I Norrish reactions, a particular functional group is photochemically cleaved, releasing a molecule of this gas.

answers: facial recognition [accept answers which indicate recognizing faces; prompt on artificial intelligence or A.I.]

China's facial recognition software is key to evaluating this national metric of "trustworthiness". A person who appears on this system's blacklist may be denied travel or job opportunities.

answers: "Investigations of a Dog" [or Forschungen eines Hundes]
"A Report to an Academy" [or Ein Bericht für eine Akademie]
parts: Name this story whose canine narrator recounts an odd incident in which seven animals sang music, which later turns out to have been a circus performance.

Franz Kafka, the author of "Investigations of a Dog," also wrote a story about Josephine the Singer, who is one of these animals. The Nutcracker defeats a king of these animals in a story by E. T. A. Hoffman.
This other Kafka story is told from the perspective of the intelligent ape Red Peter, who recounts having trouble with alcohol as he learned to behave like a human.
